column4: Yes, the old version of grub will boot into that new kernel just fine.
Sweet, erUSUL a quick apt-cache search should show that (if it's here) right?
Haha.  Yes, it's normal for Ubuntu to keep a backup kernel, for that reason.  Though usually it will install the new one and keep the old one around.  You can check with "ls /boot".

So that's the piece I'm missing, SO it goes like this: Safe upgrade gets you all the code, configures the system for the latest kernel, then you manually make the new kernel, and configure grub to boot it???
Whoa, old school.  In Ubuntu you usually just download precompiled kernels.  You can compile ones if you want, but most people don't.
Part of getting the new precompiled kernel involves it being automatically added to grub as another option.  So you'll see multiple Ubuntu lines with different kernel numbers on them.
Ok then, skip step two, just modify grub to boot the new kernel then>
I'll check the config file, haven't looked at it...
You don't have to modify grub, it should be done automatically.
I agree that seems to be what should have happened, but explain this: 2.6.31-14-generic #48-Ubuntu SMP Fri Oct 16
2.6.31 is the kernel version.  14 is 14th Ubuntu specific patch applied to the kernel.  SMP is a compilation option for the kernel.  I don't know what 48 is for.
But I'm still not sure what you're asking.  Can you boot into Ubuntu?  What problems are you having?
It's all good - I am comparing this system to one right next to it. The other runs on 2.6.32.22-generic, this one is on 2.6.31-14-generic after doing the same update...
Both Ubuntu?  It almost sounds like one of them isn't pulling from the lucid repositories.
Either that or one didn't survive the upgrade process too well.
I'm just trying to understand why - That's possible. This one is an upgrade, the other one is a clean install :)
That (what you said) could explain some wierd error messeges I get on boot. The system still seems to run alright though.
